comments.body: Please do not edit this file.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +10,14 @@
  matrix:
    # Note: Because we have to separate the py2 and py3 components due to compiler version, we have a race condition for non-python packages.
    # Not sure how to resolve this, but maybe we should be tracking the VS version in the build string anyway?
    - TARGET_ARCH: "x86"

comments.body:
Could add `author: noreply@github.com` or similar to restrict this to PRs merged through the GitHub interface. Not sure it is worth it, but figured it deserved a mention.

Also GitHub puts that under committer not author. So maybe that doesn't actually work. Not sure. ðŸ˜•

Tried using `pushd` and `popd`, but it kept failing as can be seen in this [build](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/jakirkham/staged-recipes/build/1.0.366/job/t5oupis62nabvwyt). Switching to `cd` worked fine so have stuck with it.

Popd seems to have non zero exit if not chained. I have had success with lines like 

Pushd something && do op && popd

I'm sure there's a reason for this, but I don't know it.

Yeah, I saw some AppVeyor scripts that used this with `ps`. Maybe there is something significant there that I'm missing. Wondering if it is an AppVeyor subtlety and not related to Windows generally. Have seen similar oddities with exit codes on other CI's like [Travis CI](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/customizing-the-build/#Note-on-%24%3F).

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +63,67 @@    - cmd: |
             for /f "tokens=*" %%a in ('git ls-tree --name-only FETCH_HEAD -- .') do rmdir /s /q %%a && echo Removing recipe: %%a
    - cmd: cd ..

    # Set the CONDA_NPY, although it has no impact on the actual build. We need this because of a test within conda-build.

comments.body: Had to break onto a separate line like this as the yaml parser was getting confused by the `:` and thinking it was part of a dictionary. Doing this fixed it.
After getting this command right, I will accept no further feigning of windows ignorance from you. =)
By which you mean I was smart by copying from Stack Overflow and tweaking? ðŸ˜œ

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +62,66 @@    - cmd: git fetch https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes.git master
    - cmd: |
             for /f "tokens=*" %%a in ('git ls-tree --name-only FETCH_HEAD -- .') do rmdir /s /q %%a && echo Removing recipe: %%a
    - cmd: cd ..

comments.body: You might be able to call conda with a absolute path here and not mess with path. Not 100% sure, but it might work.

AppVeyor [balked](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/conda-forge/staged-recipes/build/1.0.4157) at my [syntax](https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/commit/d06dd0d02db1b07cd7b064808f9bb05bc16a4c20#diff-180360612c6b8c4ed830919bbb4dd459R73) when I tried that. Maybe it was getting confused with the `\`s.

[Escaping](https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/commit/73f0e7761fb10319e41f410492b3cf4aaf13660a#diff-180360612c6b8c4ed830919bbb4dd459R76) the `\`s still [didn't work](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/conda-forge/staged-recipes/build/1.0.4162).
Sadly, even if the strategy presented above is hacky, it does work reliably.
Ultimately practicality beats purity. Thanks for working on it.

Agreed. I'm sure there must be a way to get it to work as you suggest. I think having an appropriate `call` as you mentioned is key. If you come up with one, please feel free to submit a follow-up PR. I might not have more cycles for this in the near term.

    - cmd: set "PATH=%OLDPATH%"

comments.body: We need to add the update after running this script otherwise it won't work.

I see. Sure. Let's get rid of it then.

comments.body: Not so sure about this. I'd rather pin everything to the same conda-build than having same build numbers built differently.

Well, we either do this or we undo the VS2008 64-bit workaround reversion ( https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/pull/447 ). Personally, I don't care which one we do, but we should pick one. As it sits now, this is causing problems for people.

@ocefpaf - I agree with your concern, but I agree that this is the lesser of the two evils (the other being #447). I'm still holding out for this to be fixed in short order (it _shouldn't_ be complex to solve after all).

> ...it _shouldn't_ be complex to solve after all

Honestly, I don't have enough understanding of what the problem is here to say. Though I think it has something to do with the workaround added to fix VS2008 64-bit. The right people at least know about the problem at this point. However, I have the impression that one of them is out. So, that may slow the process down.

comments.body: @msarahan, do you have any idea what I need to do to force AppVeyor to exit here? I thought this would be enough, but it appears not to be the case.

Looks like the [answer](http://help.appveyor.com/discussions/questions/1981-test_script-in-powershell-how-to-exit-when-success-or-when-fail) is we can't with a success status. So, it must be exit 1. That's a bit ugly. Thoughts?
Will try removing all recipes. That should keep it fast without giving us an ugly exit status.
See subsequent PR ( https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/pull/332 ) for this strategy.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +42,46 @@install:
    # Skip if we are not in a PR.
    - cmd: if not defined APPVEYOR_PULL_REQUEST_NUMBER exit 0

    # If there is a newer build queued for the same PR, cancel this one.

comments.body:
Everything else here is as it was when proposed in the Eigen PR ( https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/pull/205 ). Simply moved.

This is the only thing that was actually added. Simply to run this script on the right VM as part of the AppVeyor setup. This may need updating if/whenever [alternative CPython's](https://github.com/conda-forge/conda-forge.github.io/issues/64) come to fruition.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +62,66 @@
    # Install workaround 64-bit support for VS 2008.
    - cmd: if "%TARGET_ARCH%" == "x64" if "%CONDA_PY%" == "27" call .CI\vs2008\setup_x64.bat

    # Use the pre-installed Miniconda for the desired arch

comments.body: Interesting. This does the _correct_ job that AppVeyor rolling builds was supposed to.
Nice.
I don't know the first thing about Power Shell, but I wonder if it would be possible to inspect the recipe for the `skip: True  # [win]` string and cancel AppVeyor in that case too.
I was thinking I opened an issue on that exact idea, but I don't seem to see one. Added one here ( https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/issues/170 ).
Thanks!
So I think rolling builds might have been fixed. ( https://github.com/appveyor/ci/issues/697 )
